docs.lead_paragraph: A new state law requiring licenses and annual inspections for about 2,000 unlicensed boarding homes where former mental patients live holds the homes responsible, for the first time, for how their residents are faring. About 80 percent of the 25,000 residents in such homes - many elderly people -are former patients of state psychiatric hospitals who have been released in the last two decades, according to state officials. Many have settled in old resort towns like Asbury Park, where they make up 10 percent of the population and where some can be seen panhandling, urinating in the streets and picking through garbage cans for food.

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since the early 1970's, when large-scale drugaddiction programs were being established, New York State's treatment facilities are being strained beyond their capaacity, according to state officials. Julio Martinez, director of the State Division of Substance Abuse Services, the state's top policy-making body in the area, said that many of the 400 residential and outpatient treatment centers around the state were operating beyond their capacity as a result of the influx of heroin into New York City from southwestern Asia since the spring of 1979.
